title: Helm Fundamentals
description: Master Helm package manager for Kubernetes including charts, releases, values, templates, hooks, and repository management.

cards.back: Helm is a package manager for Kubernetes that simplifies deploying and managing applications. It packages Kubernetes manifests into charts, supports versioning, templating, and dependency management. Think of it as apt/yum for Kubernetes.

A Chart is a collection of files describing a Kubernetes application. Contains templates (K8s manifests with variables), values.yaml (default config), Chart.yaml (metadata), and optional dependencies. Charts are versioned and can be shared.

A Release is an instance of a Chart running in a Kubernetes cluster. Same Chart can be installed multiple times with different names/configurations. Each release has a unique name and maintains its own history for rollbacks.

values.yaml defines default configuration values for a Chart. Variables like image tags, replicas, resources. Override with custom values: helm install -f custom-values.yaml or --set key=value. Values injected into templates.

Templates are Kubernetes manifests with Go template syntax. Use {{ .Values.image.tag }} to insert values, {{ if }} for conditionals, {{ range }} for loops. Helm renders templates with values to generate final K8s YAML.

cards.front: What's the structure of a Helm Chart?
cards.back: Chart directory contains: Chart.yaml (metadata), values.yaml (defaults), templates/ (K8s manifests), charts/ (dependencies), .helmignore (ignore files), README.md (docs), and optionally crds/ (Custom Resource Definitions).

cards.front: How do you install a Helm Chart?
cards.back: helm install [release-name] [chart]: helm install my-nginx bitnami/nginx. Options: --namespace, -f values.yaml, --set key=value, --version (chart version), --wait (wait for ready), --dry-run (simulate).

cards.front: How do you upgrade a Helm Release?
cards.back: helm upgrade [release] [chart]: helm upgrade my-nginx bitnami/nginx --set replicas=3. Updates existing release. Options: --reuse-values (keep current), --reset-values (use chart defaults), --install (install if not exists).

cards.front: How do you rollback a Helm Release?
cards.back: helm rollback [release] [revision]: helm rollback my-nginx 1. Reverts to previous working state. View history with helm history [release]. Each upgrade creates new revision. Rollback creates new revision pointing to old config.

Hooks are resources that run at specific points in release lifecycle using annotations. Types: pre-install, post-install, pre-upgrade, post-upgrade, pre-delete, post-delete, pre-rollback, post-rollback. Used for migrations, backups, or cleanup.

Define dependencies in Chart.yaml: dependencies list with name, version, repository. Run helm dependency update to download to charts/ directory. Parent chart can override child values. Supports condition/tags for optional dependencies.

A Repository is an HTTP server hosting packaged charts (index.yaml + .tgz files). Add repo: helm repo add bitnami https://charts.bitnami.com/bitnami. Update: helm repo update. Popular repos: Bitnami, Jetstack, stable (deprecated).

helm test runs tests defined in chart's templates/tests/ directory. Test pods with helm.sh/hook: test annotation run validation (e.g., curl health endpoint). Command: helm test [release]. Tests verify deployment success.

Use meaningful release names, version charts semantically (SemVer), document values in values.yaml, use _helpers.tpl for reusable templates, validate with helm lint, test before deploying, use --dry-run, keep charts idempotent, use hooks for setup/teardown.
